California Education Code Section 72330/College Police

Monday, June 9th, 2008

http://law.onecle.com/california/education/72330.html

MSJC BP 7610/College Police - Approved/Revised by BOT 9/13/07

“The Board has established a police department under the supervision of one Chief(s) of Police, who shall report directly to the Chief Human Resources Officer. The department(s) shall have jurisdiction to enforce the law on or near the campus(es) and other grounds or properties owned, operated, controlled or administered by the District.”

Blog:

Both Ed Code and board policy state the intent/purpose of an established cc police department. How one interprets “near the campus(es)” determines whether the PD covers a few blocks “nearby the campus(es)” as the law reads or the sphere of Menifee which is over broad in interpretation of the code. The Board of Trustees have not addressed the issue in any policy discussion. They should.

“Puente Project” back at MSJC

Wednesday, June 4th, 2008

FYI

http://www.msjc.edu/forms/news.asp?Q=387

“The goal of Puente is to assist students in transferring to four-year universities with strong writing skills.”

Blog:

The Puente Project at MSJC, was dismantled under Richard Giese upon the retirement of the faculty/counselor program coordinator. Time will tell how many enrollments in the program actually transfer to a 4-year institution and at what cost to the taxpayer? The salary expense of a full-time counselor would cover the cost of many additional class section offerings which actually would assist to increase FTES and revenue.

Menifee Valley Campus Training Exercise/MSJC

Wednesday, June 4th, 2008

FYI

http://www.msjc.edu/forms/news.asp?Q=386

“There may be loud and unusual noises as well as public safety activity occurring on the campus during that time period. Aircraft may also be used in this exercise. ”

Blog:

Lots of your tax dollars at work here with the MSJC police department as lead player. At best, a public relations display.

UCD Chancellor to step down next year/Sacbee

Tuesday, June 3rd, 2008

http://www.sacbee.com/101/story/983827.html

“The man who has been at the helm of UC Davis since 1994 announced Monday that he will be stepping down from his post in a year. He plans to take a one-year sabbatical before returning to campus as a professor plant biology.”

Blog:

A one year sabbatical, paid at full salary, with intent to return as a professor. Why would a 67 year old Chancellor return to a faculty salary for less pay than a retirement pension?

Share This

Posted in Ann Motte, News | 1 Comment »

MiraCosta hunting for interim, then permanent leader/NCTimes

Monday, June 2nd, 2008

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2008/06/01/news/coastal/oceanside/z7c0af9f45c4680c58825745800738c29.txt#nctcomments

“The Mira Costa College board is looking for someone to keep the district’s top administrative seat warm until a permanent superintendent-president is found. John Hendrickson, recently announced that he has accepted a job as chancellor of the West Valley-Mission CCD in Northern California.”

“Hendrickson, who makes roughly $217,000 a year at MiraCosta, moved into the leadership post last summer after President Richart resigned with a settlement package of cash/benefits valued at $1.6 million. Hendrickson chaired the search for a permanent president but the board scrapped that effort in April after the search committee forwarded just two applicants for consideration.”

Blog:

Why does an interim president make $217,000? Administrative salaries are not tied to performance factors but rather leap frog year after year as they make comparisons of their job positions with other CEO’s in the system. Few public administrators are public servants concerned about efficiency and the taxpayers wallet. These positions have become assured stepping stones to golden parachutes paid out by taxpayers by boards who do not govern nor demand accountability.
